item.title: Soulmask: How to Recruit More Tribe Members
item.description:
Soulmask shares an interesting plot that places you in an adrenaline-pumping survival scenario in a world teeming with danger and threats lurking at every corner. You start as a lone traveler and advance from an independent warrior to the leader of your clan by recruiting numerous tribesmen.

These recruits will become your loyal companions and assist you in your survival alongside many activities, including resource collection, base protection, and providing shelter for your farm animals. Therefore, you will need to get as many tribe members as possible to manage the workload. If you are wondering how to carry out this task, this guide can help you out.

How to Recruit More Tribe Members in Soulmask

The process of recruiting new tribe members in Soulmask is rather simple, although it will take sufficient time and effort to get one. Initially, you must locate potential recruits and engage in combat to weaken them. After that, you'll need to earn their trust before inviting them to join your clan. Here is a step-by-step guide on how to do this.

Locate the Tribesmen

To begin with, your first task is to find tribesmen scattered across the game world. You'll be focusing on recruiting either Barbarians or Outcasts . Barbarians tend to inhabit Ruins spread throughout the map, while Outcasts can be found in Barracks.

These tribesmen are initially hostile towards you, so it's wise to avoid direct confrontation with groups. Instead, try to isolate a single individual from their group and engage with them.

Deter Them

To recruit a character, your first step is to weaken them. Engage in combat with them, ensuring not to inflict fatal injuries. Continue fighting until their health drops below 20%. Once their health reaches this critical point, interact with them to choose the "deter" option. Press the designated key E to initiate the process and use your mask to temporarily render the enemy unconscious.

Gain Their Trust

With the NPC now incapacitated, it's time to seize the opportunity to earn their trust. Approach them and press E to access their inventory menu. Proceed by placing liquid food items and bandages into their inventory slots for their use. While they're unconscious, get your deterred enemy back to your base and accommodate them until they regain consciousness.

Recruit Them

While your deterred enemy is recovering, you will need to pay close attention to the Recognition score displayed in their stat bar. Make sure that it crosses 500 before proceeding with recruitment. Once the Recognition score meets the requirement, the option to Recruit them will become available. Now simply press E to welcome them into your clan.

item.title: Destiny 2: Excision Activity, Explained
item.description:
The Light and Dark saga of Destiny 2 has finally come to an end, and all the events that happened ever since the game was released now culminate in Excision, one final mission where a fireteam of 12 Guardians band together to stop the Witness once and for all.

Excision marks the end of a decade-long era in the franchise. While it's nowhere near as difficult or rewarding as Destiny 2's Salvation's Edge raid, it's an epic mission that all fans of the game should experience at least once. Here's a quick overview of what Excision is and what players can expect from it.

This article contains images for the final mission of Destiny 2's Light and Dark saga, which may count as spoilers for some players.

What Is Excision In Destiny 2?

Excision is the first-ever 12-man activity in Destiny 2 , and it became available right after Salvation's Edge was cleared for the first time by Team Parabellum. Unlike the raid, this mission is a lot easier and involves fewer mechanics. It's more of a narrative experience like other campaign missions, but with public matchmaking. You can start this mission by going to the Pale Heart and scrolling to the far-right side of the map .

All the steps in Excision are:

  1. Capture four zones and defeat Cornerstones of the Witness near the landing zone.
  2. Proceed to the next area.
  3. Defeat more Cornerstones to make Light fissures appear.
  4. Gather Light from the fissures, then deposit them in the rift.
  5. Embrace the Darkness.
  6. Grab a sword and destroy Dissenter statues.
  7. Jump to the middle platform and shoot the plates on the Witness' torso.
  8. Shoot the Witness' heart.
  9. Repeat Steps 3-8 until the Witness is defeated.

The objectives speak for themselves. Beat Cornerstone minibosses, gather Light, break statues, then initiate the damage phase. Repeat until the boss is dead. The Witness' defeat will immediately be followed by a cutscene that perfectly closes the Light and Dark saga for good while paving the way for Destiny 2's new episodic format.

Once exposed, the Witness' heart becomes an enormous crit spot. Precision weapons like Linear Fusion Rifles and Sniper Rifles work extremely well here, but mind where you stand, as the Witness' attacks deal very heavy damage.

Completing Excision for the first team will reward you with a bunch of loot, including an Exotic Engram. Replaying the mission won't guarantee another Exotic Engram, but you will get some random loot and a Pale Heart Engram or two.

item.title: Mass Effect 3: How to Get the Space Hamster Back
item.description:
While exploring the Citadel in Mass Effect 2 , players will have the opportunity to purchase a Space Hamster to keep them company for the rest of their travels. If players did this, the hamster would remain on the ship until the end of the game because, unlike Shepard's fish, it didn't have to be fed.

However, when fans return to the Normandy in Mass Effect 3 , the hamster is no longer there. Gamers don't have to lose hope, as they can get their adorable rodent companion back. This guide will tell players everything they need to know in order to get their back the Space Hamster in Mass Effect 3 .

Space Hamster Location in Mass Effect 3

In Mass Effect 3 , the team will change considerably. While players will have some of their old squadmates back, like Garrus and Liara, they won't be able to recruit other familiar faces, such as Jack and Grunt. They can check up on these characters if they made it out of the Suicide Mission alive, but that's about it.

In the previous game, Jack used to hang around Engineering on the lower level. Now that she's no longer in this area, the Space Hamster made it his home. To find the Space Hamster in Mass Effect 3 , take the elevator to Deck 4: Engineering, enter the corridor that leads to Main Engineering, and go down the stairs - the hamster can be found there.

How to Capture the Space Hamster

The Space Hamster can definitely be hard to capture in Mass Effect 3 , as it moves quite quickly. The best way is to stand in the middle of the engineering deck, as it gives players time to spot it and analyze its movement before it hides.

Gamers need to be able to get close enough to the hamster so that the red lines appear around it. They should press the interact button repeatedly so that when it happens, Shepard will automatically capture it instead of missing their chance.

If the player isn't able to catch the Space Hamster on their first try, they can simply wait, and it will come out from hiding a few moments later.

Once gamers have captured the Space Hamster, they'll find it in Shepard's cabin, on top of the shelf next to the bathroom door. Players can interact with the Space Hamster at any time.

If fans complete the Citadel DLC, they'll be able to witness a funny moment in which Shepard finds the hamster's habitat in the Galaxy Map room after enemies have overtaken the ship and flag the creature as disposal - thankfully, this will not actually happen.

item.title: 5 Best Developer's Rooms In Games, Ranked
item.description:
Highlights

  • Players can discover hidden developer rooms in games like The Talos Principle and Final Fantasy 4 for a unique behind-the-scenes experience.
  • Deus Ex: Invisible War features a developer room accessed through a toilet flush, adding a quirky touch to the game's secrets.
  • In The Stanley Parable, players can unlock a meta museum ending to learn about the game's development process.

Secrets in video games are a lot of fun to uncover, and some gamers especially love the secrets that are meta and directly reference the development process in some form or another. It's easy to see why fans passionate about certain video games would love to find out everything they can about how said titles were made and the faces behind the names that appear in the credits.

The cheekiest and most intriguing way most games go about this is by adding a secret room full of actual developers who worked on the title, which is a fun thing to discover and even more engaging to explore. A lot of titles have experimented with the concept of a developer's room , and some of these secret rooms have become legendary for all the right reasons.

5 Robots With Developer Faces On Them (The Talos Principle)

Present Behind A Fake Wall In The First Lobby

The Talos Principle came out of nowhere and wowed players with its unique worldbuilding, excellent puzzle design, and a unique philosophical story about what it means to be human. The puzzles do a great job of helping players become familiar with the core concepts of the game before later levels start throwing out tougher brain teasers that are quite satisfying to complete.

Players who love this title and want to check out all the secrets present in this game may not be aware of the one present in the very first lobby. There's a fake wall here that players can cross to find a portal that leads them to the dev room, with the robots here having their heads replaced by the pictures of the developers. It's a neat addition to the game that many players will love to explore before going back and solving more puzzles.

4 The Developer's Office (Final Fantasy 4)

Was Removed And Added Back In Because Of A Questionable Item

Lali-ho! is a term that Final Fantasy 4 that most fans are pretty familiar with, given that every dwarf in the game's underground section can't get enough of saying this cheerful phrase. In a way, the jovial nature of the dwarves bleeds into each and every facet of the castle they populate, so it's easy to see why one of the most cheerful locations in an otherwise dark and foreboding title houses a secret dev room.

This area can be accessed in a hidden passage to the right of the Lali-ho Pub, where a bunch of sprites act as stand-ins for the developers. One interesting thing to note here is that this room was cut from the original Western release of the game because of an adult magazine that could be found here, which wouldn't have passed Nintendo's strict censorship laws at the time. It was added back in later releases, with the mention of this magazine being whittled down to a naughty innuendo.

3 In The Snowed-Over UNATCO Base (Deus Ex: Invisible War)

Unlocked After Flushing The Toilet In Manderley's Office

There's no denying that players had their fair share of problems with Deus Ex: Invisible War that prevented it from reaching the same heights as its predecessor. Despite its attempts to dumb down the wonderfully complex gameplay of the first game, there are still some highlights in Invisible War that make it worth checking out for fans of the debut. This includes a developer room that gamers can access by messing around with the flush in Manderley's Office.

Players will be teleported to a party in the game with various NPCs who are meant to serve as stand-ins for the developers, along with various data cubes and flaming penguins to add to this room's odd nature. It's a pretty neat secret to uncover, although players can only leave this room by reloading an earlier save, which can either elicit mild irritation or rampant frustration depending on how frequently players save their game.

2 A Meta Museum (The Stanley Parable)

Present In One Of The Game's Endings

The Stanley Parable takes on the guise of a walking simulator to let players check out an experimental title where their decisions govern the ending they get. A huge part of what makes this game special is the many endings that players can pursue, which are pretty unique and hilariously narrated to make them even more worth checking out. From fun stories to meta-narratives where the Narrator is replaced in some instances, there's no end to the sheer number of unique scenes present in the game.

One of these endings sends players to a museum where they can witness the development of the game and the many rooms that were added to the experience, making for a rather fascinating look at the thought process that went into creating the title. It's a fascinating ending, and it's sure to impress fans who wish to experience everything The Stanley Parable has to offer.

1 A Secret Room Full Of Developers (Chrono Trigger)

Unlocked After Beating Lavos In The Very First Encounter Or His Souped-Up Version In The Ocean Palace

Being one of the best JRPGs ever made, it's easy to see why so many gamers love Chrono Trigger to bits. This JRPG set the bar that future games in the genre strove to reach time and time again, with a time-bending narrative and a unique way to tackle the final boss helping this title stand out from most other games in the genre. Depending on the time in the game when players defeat Lavos, they can unlock a wealth of different endings that make sense with the right context.

One of the toughest endings to achieve in the game is the one where players either fight and beat Lavos at the start of the game (with only Crono and Marle) or try and beat the tougher version of this boss in Ocean Palace. Doing so transports players to the End of Time, with this area being populated with sprites named after the developers. Suffice it to say, players will have a great time checking out the thoughts of the people who worked on this masterpiece as a reward for completing a tough challenge and beating Lavos in the unlikeliest of instances.

item.title: New 5v5 Hero Shooter Game Announced at Xbox Games Showcase
item.description:
Highlights

  • FragPunk, a new 5v5 hero shooter, wowed gamers with its announcement during Xbox Games Showcase.
  • Call of Duty Black Ops 6 also impressed players with new movement and gameplay systems.
  • FragPunk offers unique gameplay with a deck of over 70 cards to alter match dynamics.

The new 5v5 hero shooter FragPunk was announced during Xbox Games Showcase. Gamers eagerly anticipated the June 9 Xbox Games Showcase, although many did not expect to be surprised by the sheer amount of games announced. Plenty of gamers were impressed by the amount of releases that appear to be juggling exciting gameplay, polished visuals, and quickly approaching release dates in addition to this new FPS.

Plenty of gamers were most excited about Call of Duty Black Ops 6 , which was shown off and seems to be fulfilling the expectation that players have for a standard first-person shooter. Black Ops 6 did introduce new movement systems along with an overhaul to gameplay systems to keep the release fresh while still impressing new and longtime players. There do appear to be other shooters arriving on systems too, such as FragPunk .

FragPunk , a brand new 5v5 hero shooter, was announced for Xbox Series systems and PC with a trailer at Xbox Games Showcase. The quick trailer matched the fast pacing of the gameplay itself, set in what first time developer Bad Guitar studio describes as a vibrant futuristic universe. Plenty of the gameplay of FragPunk presents is the first-person hero shooters that gamers have become familiar with, with a "radical" new change. Through the inclusion of a deck of over 70 cards, players will be able to alter the flow of matches in unique ways, such as making heads bigger to take enemies out faster, or "Chain Reaction," which will generate chain lightning through bullet contact.

FragPunk Reveal Trailer Promises Always Changing Gameplay

FragPunk boasts stylish visuals combined with thematically similar gameplay, indicative of a match that can change at any second. The game will include 10 heroes to pick from, 14 weapons, 4 maps, and systems that allow players to capitalize on the various synergies and counterplays that these elements create. The game is stated as competitive, which means it may create an opportunity for dedicated players to lead it into a similar space as other popular strategic hero shooters like Valorant which just got its own console announcement.

Some gamers were quick to point out the similarity that FragPunk bears to Friends vs Friends , Brainwash Gang's 2023 release that offers players 1v1 or 2v2 matches with the use of a card system to alter gameplay. The overall larger scale and promise of a competitive scene with FragPunk appears to be drawing the attention of many other players. Some appear to be enticed by the free-to-play aspect of the game. Plenty of gamers are looking forward to seeing more of FragPunk by the time of its slated 2025 release.
